definitions: move very quickly and forcefully in an uncontrolled manner
put or store liquid or goods inside a wooden cylindrical container
examples: The truck barreled down the mountain road dangerously
She barreled through the crowd toward the exit
They barrel the whiskey for at least twelve years
The brewery barrels its beer in oak containers

definitions: block or defend a place with an improvised barrier to prevent passage
shut oneself inside a place and prevent others from entering for protection
examples: Protesters barricaded the street with overturned cars and debris
The police barricaded the area before the demonstration began
The family barricaded themselves inside the house during the storm
Students barricaded themselves in the library to protest peacefully

definitions: exchange goods or services directly without using money as payment
negotiate or haggle over the terms of an exchange or trade deal
examples: Farmers often barter their crops for tools and supplies
The tribes bartered furs for guns with European traders
She bartered with the vendor for a better price
They bartered for hours before reaching an agreement

definitions: use something as the foundation or starting point for development
establish or locate the main center of operations in a particular place
derive ideas or principles from a particular source or set of facts
examples: The company based its strategy on market research data
They base their teaching methods on modern educational theory
The organization is based in New York with offices worldwide
Our team will be based at the field station
She based her novel on true historical events entirely
The film was based on a bestselling autobiography

definitions: strike hard and violently with a heavy blow or impact
criticize or attack someone or something harshly and repeatedly in speech
examples: He bashed the door with his shoulder trying to open it
The waves bashed against the rocks during the storm
Critics constantly bash the government's new economic policies publicly
The media bashed the celebrity for her controversial statement

definitions: lie or relax in warmth and light especially from the sun
take great pleasure or satisfaction in something pleasant or successful
examples: The cat basked in the warm afternoon sunshine contentedly
Tourists bask on the beach during their tropical vacation
She basked in the glory of her recent promotion
The team basked in their championship victory for weeks

definitions: strike or hit a ball with a wooden or metal club
open and close the eyelids quickly in a fluttering motion
take one's turn as the batter in baseball or cricket games
examples: She batted the ball over the fence for a home run
He batted away the flies with his newspaper repeatedly
She batted her eyelashes flirtatiously at the handsome stranger
He didn't even bat an eye at the shocking news
Our team will bat first in today's cricket match
He batted fourth in the lineup throughout the season

definitions: process or deal with things in groups rather than individually
organize or arrange items into groups for efficient handling or processing
examples: The factory batches orders together for more efficient shipping
We batch process all the invoices at month's end
She batched the cookies by type before packaging them
The system automatically batches files for backup every night

definitions: wash one's body by immersing in water or taking a shower
immerse or soak something in liquid for cleaning or treatment purposes
suffuse or flood an area with light or other atmospheric quality
examples: She bathes every morning before going to work downtown
Parents bathe their newborn baby very carefully and gently
The nurse bathed the wound with antiseptic solution twice daily
They bathed the fabric in dye for several hours
Moonlight bathed the garden in a soft silver glow
The sunset bathed the mountains in golden orange light

definitions: strengthen or secure something using strips of wood or metal material
secure ship's hatches with tarpaulins and wooden strips against storms
thrive or prosper at the expense of others through exploitation
examples: Workers battened the roof tiles before the hurricane arrived
They battened the loose boards with metal strips securely
The crew battened down the hatches as storms approached
Sailors battened everything movable on deck before rough seas
The company battened on government subsidies for years unfairly
Parasites batten on their hosts drawing nutrients from them

definitions: strike repeatedly with hard blows causing damage or injury persistently
damage or wear something down through repeated physical impact or abuse
coat food with a mixture of flour and liquid before cooking
examples: Heavy waves battered the coastline during the violent storm
The boxer battered his opponent with powerful punches repeatedly
Years of storms have battered the old lighthouse structure
The ship was battered by huge waves throughout the night
She battered the fish before frying it in hot oil
The chef batters the vegetables for tempura style cooking

definitions: engage in combat or warfare against an enemy or opposing force
struggle with determination against a problem or difficult situation persistently
examples: The two armies battled for control of the strategic position
Knights battled fiercely on the medieval tournament grounds daily
She battled cancer for three years with incredible courage
The company battles to maintain its market share constantly

definitions: make a deep prolonged howling cry especially of hunting dogs
force into a position where escape is difficult or impossible
examples: The hounds bayed at the moon throughout the night
Wolves bayed in the distance creating an eerie sound
The hunters bayed the fox against the cliff wall
Police bayed the suspect in an abandoned warehouse building

definitions: stab or kill with a blade attached to a rifle barrel
attack or charge at someone using a rifle-mounted blade weapon
examples: Soldiers bayoneted the enemy in close combat during battle
The guard bayoneted the attacker who breached the perimeter
Troops bayoneted their way through enemy lines at dawn
Infantry bayoneted the defenders when ammunition ran out completely

definitions: bring a boat or ship onto a beach or shore deliberately
cause a whale or marine animal to become stranded on shore
examples: The captain decided to beach the damaged vessel safely
Fishermen beach their boats at high tide every evening
The storm beached several whales along the eastern coastline
Strong currents beached the yacht on the sandy shore

definitions: send signals using a light or fire especially for navigation
serve as a guide or warning signal to others through example
examples: The lighthouse beaconed ships away from dangerous rocks nightly
They beaconed their location to rescue teams using flares
Her success beaconed hope to struggling artists everywhere persistently
The monument beacons freedom to all who see it

definitions: form into small round drops like beads of liquid or moisture
decorate or ornament something by attaching small decorative spheres to it
examples: Sweat beaded on his forehead during the intense workout
Morning dew beaded on the spider web beautifully
She carefully beaded the wedding dress with tiny pearls
Artists beaded the ceremonial costume with colorful glass pieces

definitions: emit or send out rays of light or energy in a directed way
smile broadly with obvious pleasure or pride showing joy radiantly
transmit radio or electronic signals in a specific direction purposefully
examples: The lighthouse beamed its warning light across the harbor
Sunlight beamed through the stained glass windows magnificently
She beamed with pride at her daughter's graduation ceremony
The winner beamed at the crowd holding her trophy
The satellite beams television signals to remote areas continuously
They beamed the message into deep space hoping for contact

definitions: carry or transport something heavy from one place to another
support the weight or responsibility of something without breaking
give birth to offspring or bring a child into the world
tolerate or endure something difficult or unpleasant with patience
produce fruit or crops as a natural process of growth
examples: Porters bear heavy loads up the mountain trail daily
She bore the groceries into the house with difficulty
The bridge can bear the weight of heavy trucks safely
These columns bear the entire weight of the roof
She bore three children in five years of marriage
The queen bore an heir to the throne finally
He couldn't bear the pain any longer without medication
She bore the criticism with dignity and grace admirably
This tree bears delicious apples every autumn season regularly
The investment bore excellent returns over ten years

definitions: boldly confront or challenge someone in their stronghold or territory
remove or trim the beard from someone's face using cutting tools
examples: The journalist bearded the corrupt politician in his office
She bearded the lion in his den demanding answers
The barber carefully bearded the customer with precision scissors
Soldiers were bearded before the formal military inspection ceremony

definitions: strike someone or something repeatedly with force causing pain
defeat an opponent in a game or competition through superior performance
mix ingredients vigorously with rapid stirring or whisking motions repeatedly
pulsate or throb with a regular rhythm like a heart
patrol or travel regularly through an area as routine duty
examples: The rain beat against the windows during the storm
He beat the drum with increasing intensity and rhythm
Our team beat the champions in yesterday's final match
She beat all her competitors to win the gold medal
Beat the eggs until they become light and fluffy
The chef beats the cream for the dessert topping
His heart beat rapidly after climbing the steep stairs
The music's bass beat pounded through the nightclub speakers
Police officers beat this neighborhood on foot every night
The guard beats his rounds every two hours precisely

definitions: make something or someone more beautiful through decoration or improvement
enhance the aesthetic appearance of a place through deliberate improvements
examples: She beautified her garden with colorful flowers and shrubs
The city beautified the downtown area with new sculptures
Volunteers beautified the neighborhood by planting trees everywhere
The committee beautified the park with fountains and benches

definitions: work very hard and industriously at a task with persistent determination
examples: Students beavered away at their final projects all weekend
She beavered through the pile of paperwork methodically

definitions: begin to be something or come to be in a particular state
be suitable or flattering to someone's appearance or dignity appropriately
examples: She became a doctor after years of medical training
The situation became dangerous when protesters arrived suddenly
That dress really becomes you with its elegant design
Such behavior doesn't become a person of your standing

definitions: provide with a place to sleep or accommodation for the night
plant seeds or plants in a prepared area of soil firmly
fix or embed something firmly in a surrounding mass or substance
have sexual intercourse with someone as an intimate physical act
examples: The shelter beds fifty homeless people every winter night
We bedded the horses in fresh straw for comfort
She bedded the tulip bulbs before the first frost
Gardeners bed new plants in spring for best results
Workers bedded the pipes in concrete for extra stability
The stones were bedded in mortar to prevent movement
Historical novels often mention kings bedding their mistresses secretly
The scandal involved him bedding his secretary last year

definitions: complain loudly or grumble about something in an annoying way
strengthen or reinforce something by adding extra resources or support
examples: Customers constantly beef about the high prices these days
He beefed about having to work overtime again yesterday
The company beefed up security after the break-in incident
They beefed their proposal with additional supporting data

definitions: make a short high-pitched electronic sound as a signal or warning
signal or communicate with someone using an electronic beeping device
examples: The smoke alarm beeps when the battery runs low
Cars beep their horns in heavy traffic constantly
The doctor was beeped during the emergency surgery situation
Please beep me when you arrive at the airport

definitions: happen to someone or something especially as something bad or unfortunate
examples: A terrible tragedy befell the family last winter unexpectedly
Whatever befalls us, we must remain strong and united

definitions: act as a friend to someone by offering help or support kindly
examples: She befriended the new student who seemed lonely and lost
The organization befriends elderly people living alone in isolation

definitions: ask for money or food as charity from strangers publicly
ask for something desperately or humbly with urgent emotional appeal
ask someone earnestly or humbly for something as a favor
examples: Homeless people beg for money on the street corners
The poor man begged for food outside the restaurant
She begged him not to leave her alone tonight
The prisoner begged for mercy from the harsh judge
I beg your pardon for my rude behavior earlier
Students begged the professor for an extension deadline

definitions: reduce someone to poverty or make them extremely poor through actions
be beyond the limits of something making description or belief impossible
examples: The medical bills beggared the family despite their insurance
Gambling debts beggared him within just two years
The beauty of the sunset beggars description completely
Her generosity beggars belief considering her modest income

definitions: perform or undergo the first part of an action or activity
come into existence or have its starting point at a particular time
examples: She began learning Spanish at age forty enthusiastically
The meeting will begin at nine o'clock sharp tomorrow
The trail begins at the parking lot near town
Problems began when the new management took over

definitions: act or conduct oneself in a specified way in particular circumstances
conduct oneself in accordance with accepted norms showing good manners
function or perform in a particular way under specified conditions
examples: Children behaved badly during the long car journey yesterday
She behaves differently when her boss is present
The teacher told students to behave during the assembly
Please behave yourself at your grandmother's house tonight
The car behaves strangely when driving up steep hills
This material behaves like metal under extreme pressure

definitions: kill someone by cutting off their head as a form of execution
examples: The king ordered guards to behead the traitor publicly
Many nobles were beheaded during the French Revolution period

definitions: see or observe something or someone especially something remarkable or impressive
examples: Behold the beauty of the sunset over the mountains
Visitors behold amazing artifacts in the ancient temple ruins

definitions: secure a climbing rope by winding it around a cleat or pin
stop or cancel an order or action especially in nautical contexts
examples: The climber belayed his partner from a secure position above
Always belay the rope properly before your partner climbs
The captain shouted to belay that last order immediately
Belay the preparations until we receive further instructions

definitions: accept that something is true or real without requiring absolute proof
have religious faith or trust in the existence of something spiritual
think or suppose something to be the case based on available information
examples: She believes every word he tells her completely
Scientists believe the theory explains the phenomenon accurately
They believe in God and attend church every Sunday
She believes in the power of positive thinking strongly
I believe she went to Paris for the weekend
We believe the meeting starts at three o'clock

definitions: attach a bell to something for identification or warning purposes
flare out in shape like the mouth of a bell gradually
examples: Farmers bell their cattle to track them in pastures
They belled the cat to warn birds of danger
Her skirt belled out as she spun around dancing
The trumpet bells at its end for better sound

definitions: shout something in a loud deep voice expressing strong emotion
make a loud deep roar like that of a bull or large animal
examples: The sergeant bellowed orders at the new recruits constantly
He bellowed in pain when the doctor touched his injury
The bull bellowed angrily at the approaching strangers
Elephants bellowed warnings to protect their young calves

definitions: swell or bulge outward like a full belly from internal pressure
examples: The sails bellied out in the strong ocean wind
His shirt bellied in the breeze as he walked

definitions: be the property or possession of a particular person or thing
be a member of a group or organization through formal association
be suitable or appropriate in a particular place or situation naturally
be rightly placed or classified in a particular category or location
examples: This book belongs to the library downtown
The car belongs to my neighbor across the street
She belongs to several professional organizations
He belongs to the local country club
You don't belong here without proper authorization
These dishes belong in the kitchen cabinet
This painting belongs in a museum not a warehouse
That file belongs under the classified documents section

definitions: hit someone or something hard with a belt as punishment
fasten or secure something with a belt or similar band tightly
sing or play music loudly and forcefully with great energy
move or travel very fast at high speed recklessly
examples: In the past, parents would belt misbehaving children harshly
He threatened to belt anyone who touched his car
She belted her coat tightly against the cold wind
Workers belted the cargo securely for safe transport
The singer belted out the national anthem powerfully
She belted the high notes with incredible vocal strength
The car belted down the highway at dangerous speeds
He belted around the corner nearly losing control

definitions: remove a player from active participation in a sports game
exhibit an animal at a show while seated on a bench
examples: The coach benched the star player for arguing with referees
He was benched for the entire second half yesterday
Dog owners bench their pets at the annual show
She benched her prize poodle at three competitions

definitions: shape or force something into a curve or angle physically
move the upper body downward and forward by flexing at waist
change direction by following a curved path rather than straight
force someone to submit to one's will through pressure or influence
examples: She bent the wire into a perfect circle shape
Strong winds bent the trees nearly to the ground
He bent down to pick up the fallen coins
She bent over the desk to sign the document
The road bends sharply at the mountain pass ahead
The river bends around the ancient castle walls
They tried to bend him to their will unsuccessfully
The dictator bent the people through fear and intimidation

definitions: receive an advantage or profit from something that helps improve situation
provide an advantage or improvement to someone through helpful actions
examples: Students benefit greatly from small class sizes and personal attention
The company benefited from the new tax regulations significantly
This new policy will benefit working families with children
Exercise benefits both physical and mental health tremendously

definitions: leave property or money to someone in a will after death legally
pass something valuable on to future generations as a lasting legacy
examples: She bequeathed her entire fortune to charity organizations
He bequeathed the family estate to his eldest son
The ancient Greeks bequeathed democracy to the modern world
She bequeathed her love of music to her children

definitions: gather or pick berries from bushes or plants for eating
produce berries as fruit during the growing season naturally
examples: Children love to berry in the woods during summer vacation
We spent the morning berrying in the wild blueberry patches
These bushes berry abundantly in late July every year
The plants berry best in full sunlight conditions

definitions: bring a ship into its designated mooring place at a dock
provide with a sleeping place especially on a ship or train
examples: The captain berthed the ship at pier seven carefully
Large cruise ships berth at the main harbor terminal
The ship can berth two hundred passengers comfortably
They berthed us in a small cabin near the engine

definitions: trouble or harass someone persistently from all sides with problems
surround and attack from all sides in a threatening manner
examples: Financial problems beset the company for several years continuously
Doubts and fears beset her throughout the difficult journey
Enemy forces beset the castle from every direction simultaneously
Pirates beset the merchant ship in international waters

definitions: surround a place with armed forces to capture it through blockade
harass someone with persistent requests or demands overwhelming them completely
examples: The army besieged the fortress for three months continuously
Enemy troops besieged the city cutting off all supplies
Reporters besieged the celebrity outside her home daily
Fans besieged the ticket office when sales opened
